body: Awesome! I will try it out later tonight.

Nice work! Here are some questions I had. Just wanted to know more about how you made these decisions to fill any gaps I'm missing.
- Why is information about the badge duplicated under the user? (like in line 385: information about the badge's name, description, and icon is saved)
- Why does the badge function set values to the Firebase that are already there? (like in line 402: Setting `obtained` to true when the badge has already been obtained)
- Why are `badgeAchieved` and `badgeName` the only properties returned in the callback? (line 423)
- Why does a badge have both an `obtained` property and a `dateObtained` property? (line 392)
- Why is the date the user obtains a badge saved as a date string instead of as a timestamp? (line 384)

1. The way I'm displaying the badge on the page is by putting the user's
   badge in for the ones they have made progress on. So data is necessary. The
   design could be changed to get around this.
2. That may be leftover and not necessary anymore. The main thing I was
   trying to avoid was accidentally getting rid of a property by using set.
   That specific example was for testing though.
3. Badge achieved and badge name are what I use to first trigger the alert
   when it's been achieved then use its name to let the alert have which badge
   was obtained. We could give the rest of the information, but I didn't see a
   need.
4. You're right, we could go with just date obtained, but I'm using a
   booleanClass binding to set the styles so having a boolean there is nice
   (although could it work with truthy/falsey if dateObtained exists or not).
   The date is just random information I thought would be nice.
5. I changed the string up so it would be easier to display, but we could
   do that on the website too and not in prometheus.

Hope that answers your questions.
